div.head: Capitulum 2
Concerning those receiving falsely
div.p: But those who receive without faith or false, receive the sacrament, not the thing.

Whence
Jerome :
They are bath of the gentiles, of the heretics, but they do not wash in salvation. Even in the church, those who do not receive baptism in full faith, do not receive the Spirit but water.
Hieronymus, Comment. in Ezech, IV, c. 16, 4 .

Augustine
also says:
the sacraments were common among the Jews, but grace, which is the power of the sacraments, was not common to all; thus even now baptism is common to all who have been baptized, but not the power of baptism, that is the grace itself
Augustinus, Enarrat. in Ps. 77, n. 2 (PL 36, 983) .

The same one says:
everyone who is constituted freely of his own will, when they receive the sacrament of the faithful, unless they repent of the old life, they are not able to begin the new life. Only children are immune from this repentance when they are baptized
Augustinus, Sermo 351 .

These and other testimonies show openly that the grace of remission is not conferred in baptism to adults who are without faith and true penitence, since nor is remission given in baptism to children, who are not able to have their own faith, without the faith of another. Therefore if someone receives falsely, not having true contrition of the heart, they receive the sacrament without the thing.

Nevertheless
Augustine
seems to say that to the one receiving falsely, who even has brotherly hate, in the moment in which they are baptized all things are forgiven but soon after baptism these things return, but he says this not by asserting, but rather by putting forward an opinion and sending forward a belief. For he says thus:
To those who are baptized with a false heart, or never gave up sin (because
the Holy Spirit of discipline will flea from what is feigned
Sapientia 1:5 ) or at this point in time having dismissed the strength of the Sacrament are replicated again through deceit; so that it is again true:
For as many of you as have been baptized in Christ
Gal 3:27 , etc., and there:
the Holy Spirit of discipline will flee from what is false
Sapientia 1:5 ; so that the sanctity of baptism clothes him with Christ, the perniciousness of dissemblance disrobes Christ from him
Augustinus, De baptismo contra Donastistas, I, c. 12, n. 19 (PL 43, 1119) .
For to return after having dismissed sin, where fraternal charity is not, the Lord openly teaches in that servant, from whom the Lord attacked having dismissed his debt because he did not wish to dismissed the debt of his fellow servant
Augustinus, De baptismo contra Donastistas, I, c. 12, n. 20 (PL 43, 1119) .
Thus the grace of baptism is not impeded, that not all sins are dismissed even if fraternal hate is preserved in the mind of him from whom they are dismissed. For yesterday is solved, and whatever remains; this hour and moment is solved before baptism and in baptism. But then one begins to be culpable in the continuation, not only of what follows, but even for what belongs to the past days, hours, and moments, to all things which are returning which were once dismissed
Augustinus, De baptismo contra Donastistas, I, c. 12, n. 20 (PL 43, 1119) .

But this, as we have already said, he did not say as an assertion; because it is show from what he says in the same book thus:
If someone dissembling receives baptism, the sins are dismissed to the them, but they are not dismissed; they choose what they wish
Augustinus, De baptismo contra Donastistas, I, c. 12, n. 18 (PL 43, 1119) . Behold you see openly, if you nevertheless intend, Augustine has said that, he did so not by asserting, but by asking, and by referring to the opinion of others.

For the same one says:
Then baptism began to make well for salvation, when this fiction had receded through true confession, which, while the hear remains in malice, the absolution of sin was not accustomed to occur
Augustinus, De baptismo contra Donastistas, I, c. 12, n. 18 (PL 43, 1119) . Therefore the sins of the one receiving in dissemblance are not removed.
